conferences.title:
Digitization:
impacts on production and consumption
conferences.description: Digitization has fostered several changes on creative industries like music and book, such as reduction of production costs, erosion of physical sales and new themes on intellectual property rights. This conference is going to debate the effects of digitization on productive chains and consumption habits, discussing the specifics of music and book industries as well as regulation challenges for policymakers.

panelists.name: Ana Letícia Fialho
panelists.resume: Director of Productive Strategy of the Secretary of Economy of Culture

conferences.title: Creative Economy and Public Policy: institutional experiences
conferences.description: According to UNCTAD’s Creative Report (2010), the Creative Economy is one of the fastest growing sectors of the world economy, not only in terms of income generation, but also in terms of job creation and exports revenue. The Creative Economy has been seen as an fast alternative strategy for countries to promote their economic growth and development, especially after the success of the British experience. As a consequence, the debate about Creative Economy has improved in the public sphere, generating public policies aimed at the promotion of cultural and creative activities. Thus, the Dialogues conference will promote the debate about the local experiences in Argentina and Brazil on the public initiatives in the promotion of the creative activities and their impacts.

panelists.name: Andrés Gribnicow
panelists.resume: Undersecretary of Creative Economy of Argentina

panelists.name: Mora Scillamá
panelists.resume: National Director of Creative Industries of Argentina

panelists.name: Martin Dowle
panelists.resume: Director of the British Council of Rio de Janeiro

conferences.title:
Cultural Value and
Culture Economic Value
conferences.description: The evaluation of culture economic impact implies qualiative and quantitative efforts to understand how society is affected, subsidizing cultural public policy. This conference is going to debate the concepts of cultural value and the economic relevance of culture, presenting limits and possibilities from theories of economic valuation when applied to cultural industries.

panelists.name: Geoffrey Crossick
panelists.resume: Crossick is Professor of Humanities at the School of Advanced Study, a postgraduate school of the University of London. He was Vice-Chancellor of London University from 2010 to 2012. In addition, he was Chief Executive of the Arts and Humanities Research Board from 2002 to 2005 and Warden of Goldsmiths College (now Goldsmiths, University of London) from 2005 to 2010.

panelists.name: Andy Pratt
panelists.resume: Pratt is an internationally acclaimed expert on the topic of the cultural industries. He is a Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts, a Fellow of the Royal Geographical Society, and an Academician of the Academy of Social Sciences. He has held academic appointments at University College London (Bartlett School of Planning) and LSE (Geography, and Urban Research Centre), King’s College, London (Culture, Media and Creative Industries). He joined City University as Professor of Cultural Economy in 2013. Andy has worked as a consultant or advisor for national and urban policy makers, and the EU, UNESCO, UNCTAD, and WIPO, and the British Council.

panelists.name: Paul Heritage
panelists.resume: Heritage is professor of Drama and Performance and Director of People’s Palace Projects, a School of English and Drama research centre and national portfolio organization of Arts Council England.  Since 1991, he has been creating arts and culture projects between the UK and Brazil, including 15 years of performance-based human rights projects with prisoners, guards and their families from São Paulo through to the Amazon region.

panelists.name: Leandro Valiati
panelists.university: Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul

conferences.title: Government spending and the Economy of Culture in Brazil

panelists.name: Frederico Barbosa
panelists.resume: Barbosa holds a PhD in Sociology from the University of Brasília (UnB) and a undergraduate degree in Anthropology from the same university. He has been a researcher at the Institute of Planning and Research (Ipea) since 1997. Professor of the Professional Master in Development and Public Policy promoted by Ipea in partnership with the National School of Public Health (ENSP / Fiocruz) and the School of Government in Health of the Federal Nucleus (Fiocruz) as well as Professor in Public Policies and Development of IPEA. Moreover, he coordinated several researches and evaluations on cultural economy and public cultural policies.

panelists.name: Ana Letícia Fialho
panelists.resume: Director of Productive Strategy of the Secretary of Economy of Culture

In addition, he was Chief Executive of the Arts and Humanities Research Board from 2002 to 2005 and Warden of Goldsmiths College (now Goldsmiths, University of London) from 2005 to 2010.

panelists.name: Rossalind Gill
panelists.resume: Gill is professor at University of London since October 2013. She studied Sociology and Psychology at Exeter University, and completed her PhD in Social Psychology at the Discourse and Rhetoric Group (DARG), Loughborough University in 1991. With an interdisciplinary background, she has worked across a number of disciplines including Sociology, Gender Studies and Media and Communications. Her career has included posts at Goldsmiths and King's College London, and she worked for ten years in the LSE's interdisciplinary Gender Institute.
